awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research:  Research on Airborne Ice Nucleating Species (RAINS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Microorganisms are abundant in the atmosphere and may play an important role in controlling cloud development, cloud chemistry and ultimately weather patterns. They do this primarily by producing proteins that catalyze the formation (nucleation) of ice crystals at significantly warmer temperatures than would normally be required for ice formation (-2 C vs. -36 C). Despite the atmosphere?s fundamental role in their dispersal, the abundance, diversity and flux of microorganisms in the atmosphere remain largely unknown. The potential of ice-nucleating microorganisms to significantly impact meteorology and promote microbial dispersal during precipitation events motivates this research.  The RAINS project will sample rain, snow and air samples at ground level, and in the lower atmosphere using remote-controlled aircraft.  The project will: (1) characterize microbial taxonomic diversity, including in precipitation that occurred between 1794 AD and present, and which is preserved in glacial ice; (2) determine the genetic diversity of microbial assemblages and of individual ice nucleating bacteria and (3) examine the functional diversity with respect to the role of precipitation and biological ice nucleation on patterns of microbial distribution.  The work will also determine which microbes carried to the Earth?s surface via precipitation present possible inoculum sources for diseases that impact humans, domestic animals, and plants. 

The RAINS project will increase understanding of biodiversity in the planetary boundary layer of the atmosphere, where important meteorological phenomena such as precipitation occur.  The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change recommended developing a better understanding of the effect of aerosols and atmospheric ice formation in order to improve climate models and forecast the impact of rising global temperature. The proposed study will increase knowledge on the nature of the most active ice nucleators in the atmosphere. Microbial ice nucleation may also allow microorganisms and certain plant pathogens to efficiently cycle between the atmosphere and surface habitats, and RAINS will contribute to ongoing efforts to assess the movement of ice nucleating microorganisms across geographical scales. Outreach efforts will take these advances into high school and college classrooms in the form of hands-on research experiences for students at both levels and will serve as the basis for high school educators to develop unique classroom activities. In addition, an international network of scientists collecting field data on the relationship between biological ice nucleator abundance, cropping patterns and precipitation in dry land regions will be established. RAINS will sponsor an international conference that brings together 10 young career scientists in the network to highlight the advances of these investigations and identify the outstanding scientific questions.

por.por_cntn:
Microorganisms are transported and ubiquitous in air, but due to the challenges associated with studying high altitudes in the atmosphere, little is known about their abundance, diversity, and impact on meteorological processes. The objective of the RAINS project was to examine the microorganisms that return to Earth’s surface in precipitation, with a special emphasis on certain species that are ice nucleation active, meaning they have properties that allow them to efficiently catalyze the freezing of water. Since the freezing of water in clouds is a prerequisite to snow and most rainfall, the key implication is that certain microbes may influence the formation of precipitation in clouds and use it as a vehicle for dispersal.

Intellectual merit: Analysis of precipitation sampled during RAINS showed that the amount of ice nucleating microbes were highest during winter, and in particular, in precipitation that was frozen (sleet or snow) or originated from nimbostratus clouds. Experiments indicated that rain drops are inefficient at scavenging atmospheric aerosols the size of most bacteria, implying their distribution and concentration in cloud water may be approximated from precipitation data. Air masses that traversed continental environments and influenced clouds produced precipitation that was enriched with ice nucleating microbes, supporting that plants and terrestrial ecosystems are likely their main sources to the atmosphere. Characterizing the microbial content of precipitation led to the identification of new bacteria capable of ice nucleation, expanding the range of species known to possess this phenotype. Snowfall sequences that are preserved as glacial ice were examined by analyzing a ~250-year old ice core from Wyoming, USA. We found that sample depths in the ice core corresponding to the Dust Bowl drought in the 1930’s contained the highest concentration of ice nucleating microbes observed in the time sequence. This implies that changes in climate and/or land use by humans (i.e., agricultural development in the western USA) has played a role in altering the environments serving as the atmospheric source of the microbes and their potential roles in meteorology.

Broader impacts: RAINS has increased understanding of the largely unexplored biodiversity in Earth’s atmosphere and how airborne microbes may affect meteorological phenomena in important ways.  The links shown between ice nucleating microbes and season, location, climate, and land use open the possibility for new research to design management systems that could increase precipitation and contribute to food security. The project trained two female graduate students and has provided opportunities for them to incorporate RAINS topics into teaching as well as present their data at international meetings. Eight undergraduate students were trained and participated in research activities during the course of the project, three of which are currently pursing graduate degrees. The professional development of a female African-American researcher was also nurtured during the project, and she recently enrolled in a PhD graduate program at Louisiana State University in the Department of Education with a focus on Science Education. We hosted a highly successful workshop for Louisiana middle school science teachers, the goal of which was to develop hands-on research experiences relevant to microbiology and atmospheric science that can be used in their classrooms. RAINS also sponsored three international conferences that brought together a total of 49 young career scientists to communicate the advances of our work, identify the outstanding scientific questions, and promote their ability to network and form new collaborations. Research from RAINS received significant coverage in the media and was highlighted in several articles (biographic, National Geographic, Nautilus Magazine, New Scientist, Popular Science, and ScienceNews) and radio/television programs (History Channel documentary “Invisible”, Dara O’Briain’s Science Club Series on BBC, and Radio New Zealand).
